a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x * (x * (1 + x) + 2 * x) - 3 * (x powr 2 - x + 2)"
shows  "P x = x powr 3 + 3 * x - 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Expand and simplify completely: \begin{align*}
x\left(x(1+x)+2x\right)-3(x^2-x+2)
\end{align*} The final Answer is x^3+3x-6
 ### Proof
 Begin by distributing in the innermost parentheses: \begin{align} &\ \ \ \ x\left(x(1+x)+2x\right)-3(x^2-x+2) \\&= x(x+x^2+2x) - 3(x^2-x+2) \end{align} Now, distribute again: \begin{align} x^2+x^3+2x^2-3x^2+3x-6
 \end{align} Finally, combine like terms to get \begin{align} \boxed{x^3+3x-6} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x * (x * (1 + x) + 2 * x) - 3 * (x powr 2 - x + 2)"
shows  "P x = x powr 3 + 3 * x - 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given the function $P(x) = x \cdot (x \cdot (1 + x) + 2x) - 3 \cdot (x^2 - x + 2)$, show that $P(x) = x^3 + 3x - 6$.

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x * (x * (1 + x) + 2 * x) - 3 * (x powr 2 - x + 2)"
shows  "P x = x powr 3 + 3 * x - 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

x\left(x(1+x)+2x\right)-3(x^2-x+2)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x * (x * (1 + x) + 2 * x) - 3 * (x powr 2 - x + 2)"
shows  "P x = x powr 3 + 3 * x - 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the value of $P(x)$ if $P(x) = x(x(1 + x) + 2x) - 3(x^2 - x + 2)$. The final answer is $P(x) = x^3 + 3x - 6$.

natural solution: Begin by distributing in the innermost parentheses: \begin{align} &\ \ \ \ x\left(x(1+x)+2x\right)-3(x^2-x+2) \\&= x(x+x^2+2x) - 3(x^2-x+2) \end{align} Now, distribute again: \begin{align} x^2+x^3+2x^2-3x^2+3x-6
\end{align} Finally, combine like terms to get \begin{align} \boxed{x^3+3x-6} \end{align}
